results.title: Spotlights: Fred Schepisi
results.brief_description: An Australian film director, producer and screenwriter. His credits include The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978), Plenty (1985), Roxanne (1987), Six Degrees of Separation (1993), Mr. Baseball (1992) and Last Orders (2001). Fred talks about his love for the craft and offers a perspective on violence.

constellations_primary.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_primary.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

results.description: Fred Schepisi is an Australian director, producer and screenwriter. His credits include The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978), Plenty (1985), Roxanne (1987), Six Degrees of Separation (1993), Mr. Baseball (1992) and Last Orders (2001). Fred talks about his love for the craft and offers a perspective on violence.
description_for_label: Fred Schepisi is an Australian director, producer and screenwriter. His credits include The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978), Plenty (1985), Roxanne (1987), Six Degrees of Separation (1993), Mr. Baseball (1992) and Last Orders (2001). Fred talks about his love for the craft and offers a perspective on violence.

group.title: Spotlights
group.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer and Tess Hall

results.title: Spotlights: Eric Bana
results.brief_description: Eric Banadinović AM, known professionally as Eric Bana, is an Australian actor. He began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997) before gaining critical acclaim as the lead in Chopper (2000).

constellations_primary.name: Eric Bana
constellations_primary.description: There must be something that draws Australian creatives like Eric Bana to darker material as they shoot to stardom overseas. Australia's penal colony past perhaps?

results.description: Eric Bana is an Australian actor who began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997). Soon after he gained critical recognition in the biographical crime film Chopper (2000). Eric discusses the influence of the car on the Australian psyche.
description_for_label: Eric Bana is an Australian actor who began his career in the sketch comedy series Full Frontal (1993–97) before gaining notice in the comedy/drama The Castle (1997). Soon after he gained critical recognition in the biographical crime film Chopper (2000). Eric discusses the influence of the car on the Australian psyche.

group.title: Spotlights
group.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer and Tess Hall

results.title: Spotlights: David Dalaithngu
results.brief_description: A Yolŋu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. He reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971) and Storm Boy (1976).

constellations_primary.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_primary.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

results.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. As an actor, he reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with principal roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971), Storm Boy (1976) and The Last Wave (1977). He also initiated and narrated the film Ten Canoes (2006).
description_for_label: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. As an actor, he reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with principal roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971), Storm Boy (1976) and The Last Wave (1977). He also initiated and narrated the film Ten Canoes (2006).

group.title: Spotlights
group.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer and Tess Hall

results.title: Spotlights: Bob Connolly
results.brief_description: An Australian film director, cinematographer and author. He is best known for his documentaries produced over the past 30 years, including The Highlands Trilogy (1983) and Rats in the Ranks (1996). More recent films include Facing the Music (2001) and Mrs Carey’s Concert (2011).

constellations_primary.name: Bob Connolly
constellations_primary.description: Australian audiences just can't seem to get enough of exploring local governments, bureaucracy and politics, whether that's through documentaries or biting social satire.

results.description: Bob Connolly is an Australian director, cinematographer and author. He’s best known for his documentaries, produced over the past 30 years, including The Highlands Trilogy (1983) and Rats in the Ranks (1996). More recent films include Facing the Music (2001) and Mrs Carey’s Concert (2011). Bob discusses the art of documentary making and acknowledging unconscious bias.
description_for_label: Bob Connolly is an Australian director, cinematographer and author. He’s best known for his documentaries, produced over the past 30 years, including The Highlands Trilogy (1983) and Rats in the Ranks (1996). More recent films include Facing the Music (2001) and Mrs Carey’s Concert (2011). Bob discusses the art of documentary making and acknowledging unconscious bias.

group.title: Spotlights
group.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer and Tess Hall

results.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
results.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.
description_for_label: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.

group.title: Spotlights
group.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer and Tess Hall

results.title: Jaara Nyilamum
results.creator_credit: Lou Bennett AM and Romaine Moreton
results.credit_line:
Dr Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung) and Dr Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Wurrung, Yorta Yorta)

Single-channel video, 7.39 mins

Filmed and edited by Dr Romaine Moreton

Co-directed by Dr Romaine Moreton and Dr Lou Bennett AM

Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet

Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM

Arranged by Iain Grandage

Produced by Stephen Snelleman

Engineered by Russell Thomson

ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
“The making of “Jaara Nyilamum” (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within Country, and from this place of rooted calmness, Country reaffirmed our Law is real. “Jaara Nyilamum” became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.” – Dr Lou Bennett AM and Dr Romaine Moreton

Dr Lou Bennett is a performer, songwriter, musical and artistic director, composer, actor, soundscape designer and academic. Lou’s research project ‘Sovereign Language Rematriation Through Song Pedagogy’ focusses on the importance and relevance of Indigenous language retrieval, reclamation, and regeneration through the medium of the arts to enhance community health and wellbeing.

Dr Romaine Moreton is an artist, writer, performer, filmmaker, and her proposes an Indigenous philosophy of storytelling and embodied knowledge, with her work constantly drawing our attention back to the importance of the breath in Indigenous cultural practices.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dr Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung), Dr Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Wurrung, Yorta Yorta)
results.description:
“The making of Jaara Nyilamum (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within Country, and from this place of rooted calmness, Country reaffirmed our Law is real. Jaara Nyilamum became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.” – Dr Lou Bennett AM and Dr Romaine Moreton

Dr Lou Bennett is a performer, songwriter, musical and artistic director, composer, actor, soundscape designer and academic. Lou’s research project ‘Sovereign Language Rematriation Through Song Pedagogy’ focusses on the importance and relevance of Indigenous language retrieval, reclamation, and regeneration through the medium of the arts to enhance community health and wellbeing.

Dr Romaine Moreton is an artist, writer, performer, filmmaker, and her proposes an Indigenous philosophy of storytelling and embodied knowledge, with her work constantly drawing our attention back to the importance of the breath in Indigenous cultural practices.
description_for_label:
“The making of Jaara Nyilamum (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within Country, and from this place of rooted calmness, Country reaffirmed our Law is real. Jaara Nyilamum became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.” – Dr Lou Bennett AM and Dr Romaine Moreton

Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet. Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM. Arranged by Iain Grandage. Produced by Stephen Snelleman. Engineered by Russell Thomson. ACMI Collection.
results.credit_line_for_label:
Single-channel video, 7.39 mins

Filmed and edited by Dr Romaine Moreton

Co-directed by Dr Romaine Moreton and Dr Lou Bennett AM

results.title: Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo for ZX Spectrum
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover & manual insert in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
“Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo” is based on a successful comic book by Stan Sakai. The hero is an anthropomorphic rabbit named Miyamoto Usagi, living in seventeenth-century Japan. Usagi is a masterless samurai (a ronin), who wanders the land, occasionally taking up work as a bodyguard.

In this game, you play as Usagi, who sword fights his opponents, bandits and ninja, who often disguise themselves as harmless villagers or priests. The aim of the game is for Usagi to rescue Lord Noriyuki, a panda who has been captured by Lord Hikiji.

The scenery beautifully detailed, and the game presents sideways scrolling action, with Usagi’s movements on the right of the screen, and the left dedicated to status information. The landscape forms an important is part of the game, with creatures lurking behind rocks or up trees. There are also rivers and chasms, which require skill to jump over safely.

The scoring system is based on karma points: good deeds increase Usagi’s karma points, while bad deeds decrease it. Each interaction with other characters must be considered in relation to karma. A larger portrait image of Usagi provides information on the mindset of Usagi. Reviewers of the game celebrated the demands on the player to think about he consequence of their actions. In addition the game requires certain etiquette to be adhered to. Usagi must bow appropriately to others, who are of the same or higher status as himself, who would often pass on information. If Usagi attacks a defenceless creature or an unarmed traveller, he loses all his karma points and he is required to commit hare-kari.
[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/samurai-warrior-the-battles-of-usagi-yojimbo/
Last accessed: 13/8/2020]

results.title: Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover & manual insert in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
“Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo” is based on a successful comic book by Stan Sakai. The hero is an anthropomorphic rabbit named Miyamoto Usagi, living in seventeenth-century Japan. Usagi is a masterless samurai (a ronin), who wanders the land, occasionally taking up work as a bodyguard.

In this game, you play as Usagi, who sword fights his opponents, bandits and ninja, who often disguise themselves as harmless villagers or priests. The aim of the game is for Usagi to rescue Lord Noriyuki, a panda who has been captured by Lord Hikiji.

The scenery beautifully detailed, and the game presents sideways scrolling action, with Usagi’s movements on the right of the screen, and the left dedicated to status information. The landscape forms an important is part of the game, with creatures lurking behind rocks or up trees. There are also rivers and chasms, which require skill to jump over safely.

The scoring system is based on karma points: good deeds increase Usagi’s karma points, while bad deeds decrease it. Each interaction with other characters must be considered in relation to karma. A larger portrait image of Usagi provides information on the mindset of Usagi. Reviewers of the game celebrated the demands on the player to think about he consequence of their actions. In addition the game requires certain etiquette to be adhered to. Usagi must bow appropriately to others, who are of the same or higher status as himself, who would often pass on information. If Usagi attacks a defenceless creature or an unarmed traveller, he loses all his karma points and he is required to commit hare-kari.
[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/samurai-warrior-the-battles-of-usagi-yojimbo/
Last accessed: 13/8/2020]
results.title_for_label: Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo
results.description:
Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo is based on a successful comic book by Stan Sakai. The hero is an anthropomorphic rabbit named Miyamoto Usagi, living in 17th-century Japan. Usagi is a masterless samurai (a ronin), who wanders the land, occasionally taking up work as a bodyguard.

In this game, you play as Usagi, who sword fights his opponents – bandits and ninjas – who often disguise themselves as harmless villagers or priests. The aim of the game is for Usagi to rescue Lord Noriyuki, a panda who has been captured by Lord Hikiji.

The scenery is beautifully detailed, and the game presents sideways scrolling action, with Usagi’s movements on the right of the screen, and the left dedicated to status information. The landscape forms an important part of the game, with creatures lurking behind rocks or up trees. There are also rivers and chasms, which require skill to jump over safely.

The scoring system is based on karma points: good deeds increase Usagi’s karma points, while bad deeds decrease them. Each interaction with other characters must be considered in relation to karma. A larger portrait image of Usagi provides information on the mindset of Usagi. Reviewers of the game celebrated the demands on the player to think about he consequence of their actions. In addition the game requires certain etiquette to be adhered to. Usagi must bow appropriately to others, who are of the same or higher status as himself, who would often pass on information. If Usagi attacks a defenceless creature or an unarmed traveller, he loses all his karma points and he is required to commit hare kari – ritual suicide.

Our version of the game is playable on the Commodore 64.

[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/samurai-warrior-the-battles-of-usagi-yojimbo/

Last accessed: 13/8/2020]

The scoring system is based on karma points: good deeds increase Usagi’s karma points, while bad deeds decrease them. Each interaction with other characters must be considered in relation to karma. A larger portrait image of Usagi provides information on the mindset of Usagi. Reviewers of the game celebrated the demands on the player to think about he consequence of their actions. In addition the game requires certain etiquette to be adhered to. Usagi must bow appropriately to others, who are of the same or higher status as himself, who would often pass on information. If Usagi attacks a defenceless creature or an unarmed traveller, he loses all his karma points and he is required to commit hare kari – ritual suicide.

Our version of the game is playable on the Commodore 64.

results.title: Penetrator for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette & cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Penetrator is a side scrolling shooter for one or two players for the Commodore 64. The player flies a fighter across the screen from left to right, dodging terrain and enemy shots and shooting enemy structures. Players can accelerate and brake their fighter but prolonged braking can stall it. Enemies become more accurate the longer the player is exposed to the radar and the danger level is shown on the player’s console. The game can also be customised for landscape and the number and positions of enemy missile and radar bases.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, published in 1982 by Melbourne House
results.description:
Penetrator is a side scrolling shooter for one or two players for the Commodore 64. The player flies a fighter across the screen from left to right, dodging terrain and enemy shots and shooting enemy structures. Players can accelerate and brake their fighter but prolonged braking can stall it. Enemies become more accurate the longer the player is exposed to the radar and the danger level is shown on the player’s console. The game can also be customised for landscape and the number and positions of enemy missile and radar bases.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, published in 1982 by Melbourne House
description_for_label:
Penetrator is a side scrolling shooter for one or two players for the Commodore 64. The player flies a fighter across the screen from left to right, dodging terrain and enemy shots and shooting enemy structures. Players can accelerate and brake their fighter but prolonged braking can stall it. Enemies become more accurate the longer the player is exposed to the radar and the danger level is shown on the player’s console. The game can also be customised for landscape and the number and positions of enemy missile and radar bases.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, published in 1982 by Melbourne House

results.title: The Search for King Solomon's Mines for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette & cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: The Search for King Solomon’s Mines [computer game] for Commodore 64. The Search for King Solomon’s Mines is a single-player text adventure for the Commodore 64. It is the first part of a two part graphic adventure and allows for saving of the adventure for pauses during play.
results.title_for_label: The Search for King Solomon’s Mines for Commodore 64
results.description: The Search for King Solomon’s Mines [computer game] for Commodore 64. The Search for King Solomon’s Mines is a single-player text adventure for the Commodore 64. It is the first part of a two part graphic adventure and allows for saving of the adventure for pauses during play.
description_for_label: The Search for King Solomon’s Mines [computer game] for Commodore 64. The Search for King Solomon’s Mines is a single-player text adventure for the Commodore 64. It is the first part of a two part graphic adventure and allows for saving of the adventure for pauses during play.
